results.title: The Demanding sea
results.brief_description: A record of life at sea. Two old sailors discuss their lives against a background of moving ships - frigates, tramps, liners, tankers, trawlers and tugs - and the sea, in all its moods, benign, stormy and ice-bound. Conveys an awareness of what the sea means.

results.title: The Deluge = Potop. Parts 1 and 2 [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Jerzy Hoffman, Wilhelm Hollender and Film Polski
results.brief_description: This is a film of epic proportions somewhat reminiscent to “Doctor Zhivago” in its grandness, its breathtaking scenery, superb cinematography (Jerzy Wojcik), evocative images and a fine cast of actors. Based on the Nobel prize-winning novel by author Henryk Sienkiewicz, “The Deluge” takes place in 17th century Poland, during the Polish-Swedish War (1655-1660) with the central plot revolving around the intense and often stormy love affair between the main character, Andrzej Kmicic (Daniel Olbrychski), a noble man and a soldier often erratic in temperament, and Olenka (Malgorzata Braunek) a young gentlewoman of strong beliefs and convictions who will over the course of their relationship, be forced to question the morality of the war and Andrzej’s involvement in it. Shot on location in Poland in many of the ancient and historic castles and accompanied by an original muscial score (by Kazimierz Serocki) which enhances and adds depth to the story, this is a war film with a difference. The myriad of characters representing all walks of life, from the peasants to the aristocracy, through to the soldiers in battle, weave in and out of the story adding a sense of realism and involvement for the onlooker. “Potop” was nominated for Best Foreign Film in the 1974 Academy Awards. Cast also includes Tadeusz Lomnicki, Kazimierz Wichniarz, Wladyslaw Hancza, Leszek Teleszynski. WARNING: The English subtitles are often out of sync, and sometimes too fast to read.

results.title: The Delinquents (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Chris Thomson, Mike Wilcox, Alex Cutler, Silver Lining Entertainment, Wilcox and Cutler
results.brief_description: Too young to be together, too in love to be apart, Lola and Brownie’s obsessive passion for each other breaks all the rules laid down by their parents and society. Quickly branded as rebels they are forced to separate but they fight all the odds to be reunited. Stars Kylie Minogue, Charlie Schlatter and Angela Punch-McGregor Based on the novel “The Delinquents” by Criena Rohan.

results.title: The Delinquents
results.creator_credit: Chris Thomson, Mike Wilcox, Alex Cutler, Silver Lining and Village Roadshow Pictures
results.brief_description: Love story about two teenagers in 1950’s Australia whose passion and love for each other breaks not only the rules set down by their parents but also by society. Based on the novel of the same name by Criena Rohan. Stars Kylie Minogue and Charlie Schlatter with Bruno Lawrence, Todd Boyce, Desiree Smith, Melissa Jaffer, Angela Punch-McGregor.

results.title: The Delinquent, the hipster and the square
results.creator_credit: Tim Kiley, Jack Kuney and CBS Television
results.brief_description: A study of the dynamics of youth culture as expressed in dominant youth reactions to the world; rebellion, escape and uncritical acceptance. Each reaction is examined dramatically and the significance pointed out critically, yet sympathetically, by the narrator Dr. William Kirkland, late professor of Christian Ethics, McCormick Theological Seminary. Written by Elliot Baker. Starring Warren Berlinger as the square, William Hickey as the delinquent, Pat DeSimone as the girl, Mal Throne as the poet and the Max Roach Quinter.

results.title: The Delights of Turkey
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger and Grainger Television Australia
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Greg Grainger journeys for 4,000 km around Western Turkey on a motorcycle. Beginning in Istanbul, home of the more liberal Turkish Muslims, we visit famous tourist venues such as the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia and the magnificent Grant Bazaar. Travelling along the coast, we see the increasing numbers of young Australians making their pilgrimage to Gallipoli at Anzac Cove. Remains of Roman civilization and architecture are evident throughout Western Turkey and Greg’s group rides in a hot air balloon over the strange cave houses of Cappadocia. Traditional farming and carpet making in rural areas are shown as happily co-existing with the more modern tourist attractions of restaurants, belly dancing and shopping in the cities.

results.title: The Delian problem (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Neil Cleminson, Jean Nunn, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Mathematics”.
Examines the problem of duplicating the cube, which amounts to finding the cubic root of 2 and is known as the Delian problem. Discusses the reformation of this problem in terms of finding two mean proportionals and the solution of the simpler problem of one mean proportional.

results.title: The Dehumanizing city...and Hymie Schultz
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hiller, George Justin, Learning Corporation of America and Colombia Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Adapted from the film “The Tiger makes out” with Eli Wallach, the theme here is the modern individual in conflict with complex bureaucratic systems. Waking up one morning to the callous impersonality of big city life, Hymie Schultz, mailman, decides to fight back. Bureaucracy, however, proves more stubborn than he, and at the end of the day defeated and helpless, he retreats, one individual lost among many.

results.title: The Defiant ones
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kramer and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Two convicts - one black, one white - escape across country chained together. Initially the yard of chain shackles two bitter enemies but gradually a bond grows between them. Dramatically and cinematically this is probably the most satisfying of Kramer’s “message” pictures but, although free of sentimentality and polemics, the notion of universal brotherhood is perhaps too simplistic to carry much conceptual interest. Winner of two Academy Awards (1958). Cast includes Tony Curtis and Sidney Poitier.
